bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 5, 1875

div1.p: Reed, in verse, declares his devotion to Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 5, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
August 5th, 75.

lg.l: Am I still your debtor,
In neglecting to write my rhyming letter?
Well, Alas! it is a crying shame,
That I should thus disgrace my name!
Really, my darling, I am afraid you'll say,
That my greatest strength lies in delay.
But listen a moment, while I relate
The cause of my unfortunate state.
Perhaps, when the reason shall appear,
You'll be inclined to drop a tear
Over the luckless effort of one,
Who was cheering his heart with a little fun.
Give ear:- I had taken my quill,
And gone to work with a right good will.
My fingers were nimble, my heart was light,
My head was as clear as the day was bright.
In fact, I do not think there was ever given
To mortal a more propitious Heaven.
I had flattered myself that this letter in rhyme
Should contain the lore of every clime:
That in a lofty style it should be writ,
Full of learning, thought & wit!
I had hoped to equal the great Mr Hannon
When firing off his biggest cannon-!
(I trust, since you've accorded him so much praise,
You'll not be surprised, if I ape his ways).
Alas! how little we mortals know
Concerning our future joy or woe!
It seems 'tis Heaven's kind decree,
That the mind of man should ever be free
From all impending calamity;
Lest, indeed, suspense like this
Should rob his soul of all its peace.
Be this as it may, I'll not complain
Of what was meant to be my m gain.
Still, occassionally, to look into dim distance
Would be of very material assistance.
As in this case, it alone could save
My effort from an early grave.
But I'll hasten on, nor longer wait
To disclose to you my unhappy fate.
I had progressed well to the forty-fifth line,
When lo! my muse began to pine!
And, in spite off all that I could beg,
She wouldn't move another peg!
While I pondered what I should do,
She stretched her wings & upward flew;
Nor did she cease her sudden flight,
Till she had gained a mountain's height,
Which, rising from a lowly bed,
Raised on high its lofty head.
There, seated on an azure peak,
This silly Goddess refused to speak!
You may know, from the way my muse had acted,
That I had gone well-nigh distracted;
So to propitiate a Being so fair,
I addressed to her the following prayer;
I homage pay from morn till night,
But still thou dost refuse;
Oh! come & touch my feeble sight,
Thou song-inspiring muse!
If thou but teach me how to sing,
A lay full soft & sweet,
The costliest treasures I will bring
And cast them at thy feet.
My hand, my heart, my life I'll bring,
And give them all for Thee;
Nor cease my grateful tongue to sing
What Thou host done for me.
Nor deem that I have scarce begun,
Thy kindness to repay,
Till all the nations, one by one,
Confess thy gentle sway.
But if thou dost my proffers spurn,
Nor stoop thy smiles to show,
My love for thee in vain shall burn,
My hopes lie scattered far & low!
Now, my darling, I'll leave it to your good sense,
If my prayer didn't deserve some recompense.
But will you believe it? (Sure I must weep)
The heedless Goddess had fallen asleep!!
Beholding this, I threw down my pen,
And declared I'd never try rhyming again!
Oh! is it not 'nough to break the heart,
When we endeavour to act our part,
(As best we can); to be rejected,
And that, the, by those we had least expected!
Ah! at such a time to feel alarm,
Removes from life its sweetest charm!
Compels our wounded souls to fly,
And seek for balm beyond the sky!
Yet, after waiting an hour or two,
I felt the spell of the breeze that blew,
Into my window & oe'r my brow,
And concluded to break my foolish vow.
If the Goddess wouldn't condescend
Neither her prescence nor smiles to lend;
Why then, not meaning, at all, to flout her,
I'd simply get along -- without her.
I'll only make this one request;
If my letter should lack or spirit or zest,
That you'll remember, as it little avails
A vessel to move without her sails,
So in rhyming, though such we choose,
'Tis hard to move without the muse!
But to my letter, & awaywith the muse away!
And first, let me tell the events of the day.
Yesterday, I went to that great City,
Where there's so much wealth & so little pity,
(My previous attempts to go were in vain,
Owing to the fall of a very heavy rain)-
Where as many houseless men are seen,
As blades of grass upon the green;
Where old age & youth, all, breathless follow,
To grasp & hold the glittering dollar;
Where no man cares a fig for a friend,
Unless he has, perhaps, a penny to lend!
On reaching this city, I turned my looks
To D. Appleton's, who deals in books.
My intention was to give a start
To that very lazy “Journal of Art-”
The clerk I saw gave no good cause
For the Journal's recent protracted pause;
And kindly promised, without delay,
To send it merrily on its way.
From the look I gave him, (one fearless & stern),
I think, in the Future he'll better learn,
And hence deprive you of the occassion
Of inflicting on me another abrasion.
When to this matter I had duly seen,
I went to the office of the “Sewing Machine”,
Where I warmly grasped & shook
The hand of my good friend, Mr Cooke.
He greeted me with as kindly a glance,
As if I'd been the King of France,
And, remarking that I looked thinner,
Compelled me to go with him to dinner.
I concluded to take a “bite & sip,”
Just by way of old friendship.
So together we crossed the River,
And soon were dining on “bacon & liver.”
Our luncheon o'er, I bade him “good-bye”,
And left one tear in his hazel eye.
(In order that you may not be mistaken,
I'll tell you 'twas due to pepper & bacon.)
Having to some other matters hastily attended,
To Willet's Point my course I wended.
The hour was such as one for contemplation best,
Just when the Setting Sun had tinged the golden West.
And there I found your very sweet letter.
Of four full pages & a little better.
I tell you, it set my head in a whirl
To get so a long a letter from my little girl.
Still, I confess, I would have blessed my fate,
If the five had only been lengthened and to eight.
(Of course, this is not meant to suggest,
As in such matters, you know what's best)
But bless my soul! How I felt bereft,
When you spoke of the way in which I'd “left.”
As in leaving, I displayed “no emotion”,
Of course, I disclosed my pretended devotion.
And for a lady so thoroughly schooled
'Twas annoying, indeed, to be thus fooled.
What, than all else, surprised me more
Was that you had failed to see this before.
Wasn't it the plainest thing to see
That there was naught nothing but coldness in me!
And how could you fail to know
That my heart was never above zero,!
Or could think that I cared at all,
For any girl on this round ball!
In sooth, woman's simplicity will ever be
To man the one, greatest mystery-
But permit me to offer a little suggestion,
Which may aid in solving this very dark question.
(If with my words you don't agree,
Imagine I'm talking to some other lady.)
“Now, my dear, if you prefer a blaze to a cinder,
Don't turn your face full to the window
When you are parting with your lover,
Or else, perhaps, he may discover
Of emotion an apparent lack
In the lady who turns upon him her back”!
But truly, my darling, all joking aside,
For once, you've missed the mark very wide;
Since in parting with you I surely cried,
And left you abruptly my tear to hide-
Satisfied of this, I think its about time
To bring to an end this wretched rhyme.!
I'm sure you'll not ask me to repeat it again,
And hence my effort has not been in vain.
In Conclusion, allow me to emphasize,
That you'll will show this to no other eyes:
(The very thought that perhaps you will,
Makes me feel a decided chill!)
However much, others may assail you,
Do you alone weep over my failure.
Finally, as the vine clings to the tree,
So clings my heart to “my little B-”
Though the waves beat high on the storm-beaten
rock,
Our love, my precious, shall ne'er feel
the shock,
Nor shall our hearts in the least e'er
alter,
Nor I cease to be your own, fond
